NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Gates foundation’s seventh annual letter includes several “big bets” from the philanthropists on what they predict will be the big breakthroughs in global health, education and agriculture. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The letter states this year’s bets were inspired by the prediction Bill Gates and his Microsoft co-founder, Paul Allen, made 40 years ago, that personal computers and software would transform people’s lives. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Some people thought they were nuts. But the bet turned out well,” said the letter. “Fifteen years ago, the two of us made a similar bet. We started our foundation in 2000 with the idea that by backing innovative work in health and education, we could help dramatically reduce inequity. The progress we’ve seen so far is very exciting – so exciting that we are doubling down on the bet we made 15 years ago and picking ambitious goals for what’s possible 15 years from now.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Gates Foundation predicts the following breakthroughs in the next 15 years: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Child deaths will reduce by half, and more diseases will be eradicated than ever before. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Diseases such as polio, guinea worm, elephantiasis and blinding trachoma will be eradicated. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The world will have a vaccine to prevent people with malaria from spreading it to the mosquitoes that bite them, a single-dose cure that clears the parasite completely out of a person’s body, and a diagnostic test to show whether a person is infected with malaria. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Agricultural productivity will increase by 50% across Africa, allowing farmers to grow a greater variety of nutritious food. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Digital banking will grow. By 2030, 2 billion people who don’t have a bank account today will be storing money and making payments with their phones.
